Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Secure Work in the Worker-Cooperative Sector

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the expanding worker cooperative sector in New York City. Three research questions will be investigated: 1) how relevant stakeholders conceive of and view worker ownership; 2) how municipal investment in the worker cooperative sector affects the worker cooperative movement; and 3) the effects of worker ownership on labor security. Through this research, issues facing workers and their communities, including the importance communities have for workers' economic well-being, will be understood better. Understanding of how workers' autonomous efforts may change when external actors become involved in promoting those efforts also will be increased. This, in turn, will inform our knowledge of how policies at local, regional, and national levels may be developed to support the creation of secure employment.

Research will proceed in two phases. The first phase will involve semi-structured interviews with different actors throughout the field of cooperative organizations in New York City, observations of cooperative sector events, and archival research. Those interviewed will include worker-owners from a purposive sample of worker cooperatives, community economic development professionals, leaders of cooperative federations and advocacy organizations, and local political representatives. In the second phase, two relevant two surveys will be analyzed, the 2017 Worker Co-op Census and three work-related modules of the General Social Survey. The products of this research, including a report on the New York worker-cooperative sector and presentations at cooperative-sector conferences and community economic development events, will be accessible to a diverse audience including community-based economic development organizations, economic development policymakers at the local, regional and national levels, workers across labor-market sectors and skill levels, and academics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates how local institutions can support the creation of secure, locally-rooted jobs by studying the worker cooperative sector in New York City. The NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement (DDRI) Grant supported three primary goals of dissertation research on worker-ownership: (1) to conduct semi-structured interviews and participant observation with multiple stakeholders across the ecosystem of worker-owned cooperatives in New York City, including worker-owners, city agency staff, nonprofit organization leaders, and political representatives; (2) to develop an original qualitative dataset based on this fieldwork; and (3) to analyze this data in terms of the project’s key concerns with (a) the transformative potential of worker-ownership (creating an alternative to existing market relations through present-day economic activity), (b) work values (the preferences and priorities individuals assign to different aspects of their jobs), (c) labor security, and (d) the effects of municipal sponsorship of worker co-ops.


In order to achieve these goals, the co-PI selected a purposive sample of worker-owned cooperatives and organizations involved in cooperative development in New York’s cooperative ecosystem. The co-PI then conducted 35 semi-structured interviews with individuals working in this sector, as well as observations at cooperative sector events (e.g., worker cooperative teach-ins, training sessions, and conferences). To create the dataset, the co-PI kept detailed fieldnotes, transcribed and translated recorded interviews verbatim, and wrote analytic memos on both fieldnotes and interviews. These documents were later coded for key themes including work values, future orientation, empowerment, and several aspects of labor security (e.g., income security, job security, skill reproduction security, work security), The co-PI then observed patterns in the data and used these to develop specific approaches for the final interpretation and concluding phases of the project.


Fieldwork showed that worker-ownership has the most “transformative potential” (substantial positive impact) for workers when this business model is “incubated” (sponsored) by community-based economic development and social service organizations. These local organizations play a vital role in creating opportunities for dignified employment, particularly in communities with high unemployment rates and a density of workers with low levels of human capital (in the forms of educational attainment and hard skills) and social capital (e.g., immigrant status and English fluency). The majority of worker-owners belonging to incubated co-ops are female immigrants with low educational attainment and/or English fluency. As such, the cooperative model offers this specific subpopulation of workers unique access to dignified work, autonomy, and a living wage that is not available through other channels; but importantly, access to these benefits is mediated through community-based organizations, demonstrating that municipal sponsorship of worker-ownership is crucial for some workers. By contrast, workers with low human capital but relatively higher social capital did not experience better work conditions or wages as a result of being worker-owners. Meanwhile, workers with both higher human and social capital as a starting point generally viewed engaging with worker ownership as a personal choice, and belonged to cooperatives that formed without the incubation, business development, and technical assistance services which are integral to community-based cooperatives. These workers, by virtue of their high human and social capital, have the option to set reservation wages and work terms independently of their affiliation with worker-owned firms.

 
Current analyses of work values in this population are consistent with the above; data show variations in work values among two distinct subgroups of fieldwork participants: U.S. citizens with a college degree and non-citizens with lower educational attainment. College-educated citizens tend to be more motivated to engage in workplace democracy as a result of intrinsic work values, whereby work represents an opportunity to use or demonstrate one’s abilities, achieve goals, express creativity, have independence and autonomy, or find fulfillment. By contrast, non-citizens with lower educational attainment tend to engage in workplace democracy as a result of extrinsic work values, whereby cooperatives offer the opportunity to work without a boss, in safe and dignified circumstances, earn fair wages, and have some degree of control over work schedules and hours. Most workers interviewed from this subgroup had endured exploitative work experiences previously and viewed cooperative organizations as a singular means to access basic labor protections, which suggests that cooperatives are a unique source of labor security mostly for marginalized workers.


Preliminary findings have been presented at academic conferences. Works in progress include articles in sociological journals, a report on the New York worker-cooperative sector, presentations at community economic development events, and regional and national cooperative-sector conferences. These products will be accessible to a diverse audience including community-based economic development organizations, economic development, workers across labor-market sectors and skill levels, as well as academics. The intellectual merit of this project includes contributions to our understanding of the relationship between prior life and work experience and current job satisfaction; the conditions under which we can develop secure employment; and contributes to our knowledge of how social relations, communities, and markets shape each other.
